questions.question_text: A site reliability engineer updated the latest configuration management scripts and committed them to a workstream called either test or patch. A Linux administrator wants to ensure these latest workstreams are able to be retrieved to the server. Which of the following is the BEST Git attribute to use?

discussion.content: D. Fetch just checks the metadata. Pull actually retrieves the scripts. Since the questions asks "ensure ...are able to be retrieved to the server", I am reading this as testing the full process (hence PULL).

Selected Answer: B
You want the branches to be able to be retrieved, so you need to git fetch. 

Git pull is for retrieving after you fetch.

D. Pull is the best option for me. 
The question says " A Linux administrator wants to ensure these LATEST workstreams are able to be retrieved to the server " (merging to the server)
git pull - get all the latest changes from the origin and merge.
git fetch - get all the changes from the origin (no merge)
(hence PULL)

git pull
https://dzone.com/articles/top-20-git-commands-with-examples
Usage: git pull 
This command fetches and merges changes on the remote server to your working director

B. fetch
ensure these latest workstreams are
able to be retrieved to the server and not downloaded with pull

choices.B: Rename the /etc/modprobe.d/watchdog file to watchdog.off instead.
choices.A: Add blacklist watchdog to the /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist file.
choices.C: Remove the watchdog=1 from the /usr/modules/watchdog.conf file.

questions.question_text: A systems administrator wants to disable the Linux Kernel WatchDog Timer Driver for security purposes. Which of the following will accomplish this task?

discussion.content: for various performance or security reasons, it is necessary to prevent the system from using a certain kernel module. This can be achieved by module blacklisting, which is a mechanism used by the modprobe utility to ensure that the kernel cannot automatically load certain modules, or that the modules cannot be loaded at all

sudo useradd -m username

Creates the new user’s home directory and copies files from /etc/skel directory to the user’s home directory.

questions.question_text: A new user has been added to a Linux machine. Which of the following directories would contain the user's default files?

An issue was discovered on a testing branch of a Git repository. A file was inadvertently modified and needs to be reverted to the master branch version. Which of the following is the BEST option to resolve the issue?

choices.B: Add the content of id_rsa file to the remote system ~/.ssh/authorized_keys location.
choices.A: Add the content of id_rsa.pub file to the remote system ~/.ssh/authorized_keys location.
choices.D: Add the content of id_rsa.pub file to the remote system ~/.ssh/known_hosts location.
choices.C: Add the content of id_rsa file to the remote system ~/.ssh/known_hosts location.

discussion.content:
Correct. You always keep your private key and only share your public key. 

If the remote system is not configured to support password-based authentication, you will need to ask system administrators to add your public key to the ~/.ssh/authorized_keys file in your account

Your private key will be generated using the default filename (for example, id_rsa) or the filename you specified (for example, my_ssh_key), and stored on your computer in a .ssh directory off your home directory (for example, ~/.ssh/id_rsa or ~/.ssh/my_ssh_key).

The corresponding public key will be generated using the same filename (but with a .pub extension added) and stored in the same location (for example, ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub or ~/.ssh/my_ssh_key.pub).

comments.content: I really like your explanation Dan. How did the test go?
